body.p: The impact of globalization and the rise of the multinational firm have been the focus of much research in management. In fact, almost the entire field of international business has focused on understanding and theorizing about these important organizations. More recently, the question of how businesses can be made more sustainable has begun to capture the attention of management scholars with an increasing number of scholars beginning to explore the nature of sustainable enterprise (e.g., Kurland & Zell, 2010; Nidumolu, Prahalad, & Rangaswami, 2009; Westley & Vredenburg, 1996). In this article, leading scholars in sustainability take on the thorny question that lies at the intersection of these two literatures: What constitutes a sustainable global business? More specifically, can we obtain the benefits of globalization without the very negative impacts on the environment and the social well-being of the poorest nations that have occurred to date? The result is an engaging and thought-provoking discussion about the nature of sustainability and how this concept can be applied in the complex context of the multinational firm.
